text:
Hi all,
I'm pretty new to coding in general as i'm petroleum engineer.
i'm looking for a career shift and interested in scientific programming.
i recently started to produce some staff on python.
recently i passed by some MIT courses about scientific ML and numerical methods, all were in Julia.
just need to know, will Julia be a perfect choice for career shift to AI and ML or a perfect tool to facilitate the learning and experimentation ?

elements.text:
Hi all,
I'm pretty new to coding in general as i'm petroleum engineer.
i'm looking for a career shift and interested in scientific programming.
i recently started to produce some staff on python.
recently i passed by some MIT courses about scientific ML and numerical methods, all were in Julia.
just need to know, will Julia be a perfect choice for career shift to AI and ML or a perfect tool to facilitate the learning and experimentation ?

text: Python currently dominate the ML and deep learning landscape. That's probably going to change, since most big companies have realized Python is not such a good fit for these purposes. But I would expect Python to continue dominating for at least five years, and probably ten. Compared to Julia, Python also have a much larger ecosystem of software to use, so whatever the field you're in, there is a good chance there are more Python libraries than Julia libraries.

elements.text: Python currently dominate the ML and deep learning landscape. That's probably going to change, since most big companies have realized Python is not such a good fit for these purposes. But I would expect Python to continue dominating for at least five years, and probably ten. Compared to Julia, Python also have a much larger ecosystem of software to use, so whatever the field you're in, there is a good chance there are more Python libraries than Julia libraries.

text:
So overall, I would probably learn Python first. Julia is a deeper language with more flexibility. It is capable of more than Python, more complex than Python, while also being a great place to learn from. Most notably compared to Python, Julia allows metaprogramming and can produce fast, efficient code. The reason Julia is a good teaching language is because it's unique in combining the interactiveneness and dynamicness with raw speed.
Incidentally that also makes it more suitable for data science and machine learning, but again... Python has all the best libraries, still

text: for a career change, no, I'd still stick with python - that'll give you way better chances on the job market.

elements.text: for a career change, no, I'd still stick with python - that'll give you way better chances on the job market.

text: switching to julia afterwards or learning it in your spare time and introducing it at your job that way is the safer bet

text:
> for a career change, no, I'd still stick with python - that'll give you way better chances on the job market.
What? No. Definitely not. The hiring market in Julia is huge right now. It's a job seeker's game.

elements.text: for a career change, no, I'd still stick with python - that'll give you way better chances on the job market.

text:
It feels like there is more demand than supply for people with good Julia experience, finally (but that’s only recently)
I agree with Chris.
Also, there are so many people who have years of Python experience, it would be a lot heavier competition.

text: Another thing, PyCall makes it relatively easy to utilize Python libraries in Julia, so if you learn about the relevant parts of the Python ecosystem for your work, you can just use them from Julia

elements.text: Another thing, PyCall makes it relatively easy to utilize Python libraries in Julia, so if you learn about the relevant parts of the Python ecosystem for your work, you can just use them from Julia

text:
I am a Chemical Engineer myself which is sort of related to Petroleum Engineer. I personally coded python interfaces and routines in Fortran90/95 to calculate thermodyamical properties in oil reservoirs for an oil company. That was a lot of work at the time and I wish I would have had Julia instead.
As of ML and AI, I personally think that it is sort of a fad that has been hyped for the last years. I'm not saying that will go away, but will be incorporated into "normal" science and engineering as an everyday tool. I foresee that what Chris is doing with SciML will be one of the things that ML and AI will morph into. In that sense investing on numerical methods and SciML with focus on high performance is a better career move and the best way to achieve that is with Julia which I believe is spearheading this.

text:
This discussion is of great interest for me as I currently have no employment and I’ve been trying to figure out which direction I want to go. I have a lot of experience in Java and Salesforce, somewhat less in Python, and somewhat less than that in R and ML. I’ve been getting quite many contacts regarding Java, but my heart is not there right now. I’ve been learning Julia for two months, and Julia plus ML is really what I would like to do. It’s just that at the moment there does not seem to be any job market for Julia in Finland.
Whichever direction I go means that I will spend an effort learning more in that area and a lot less in others.

elements.text:

It’s just that at the moment there does not seem to be any job market for Julia in Finland.
Whichever direction I go means that I will spend an effort learning more in that area and a lot less in others.

text: Do you have scientific modeling, differential equations, and/or ML background? Throwing it out there: if you do, just contact me please. No guarantees but I am looking for people in this SciML space (and we've already hired the people I knew to hire!)

elements.text: Do you have scientific modeling, differential equations, and/or ML background? Throwing it out there: if you do, just contact me please. No guarantees but I am looking for people in this SciML space (and we've already hired the people I knew to hire!)

text:
I don’t feel ML is a fad, but there is a lot of undisciplined use of ML techniques, IMO (I.e. throw lots of data at a ML toolkit and see what pops out). I think there may be a backlash to that sort of thing.
What Chris is doing with SciML is quite different, and I think it will grow a lot in importance.

elements.text:
I don’t feel ML is a fad, but there is a lot of undisciplined use of ML techniques, IMO (I.e. throw lots of data at a ML toolkit and see what pops out). I think there may be a backlash to that sort of thing.
What Chris is doing with SciML is quite different, and I think it will grow a lot in importance.

text: About the job market in Finland, what about remote work for the time being? I think we’ll be stuck until late next year in this situation, so many companies will still be open to hiring remote workers

elements.text: About the job market in Finland, what about remote work for the time being? I think we’ll be stuck until late next year in this situation, so many companies will still be open to hiring remote workers

text: Traditional ML is for big data issues, which NLP and image processing are in. But it's not for all problems. That doesn't mean it's a fad, it just means calling it the next industrial revolution is hype, and actually making it span to new disciplines will take a lot of effort to tailor it to include the prior knowledge of the different fields.

elements.text: Traditional ML is for big data issues, which NLP and image processing are in. But it's not for all problems. That doesn't mean it's a fad, it just means calling it the next industrial revolution is hype, and actually making it span to new disciplines will take a lot of effort to tailor it to include the prior knowledge of the different fields.

text:
<@UB7JS9CHF> I do think that it is a fad because many people think what you just described, just throw some data at an automated hyper-curve fitting (AKA ML) toolkit and magically get some model (fit) that sometimes works and when it doesn't, people don't know why and/or can't scale it. Then they realize that these techniques are very hard to use if you don't have domain (actual) knowledge. The techniques are not a fad, but the hype and the expectation that it will (magically) solve everything without much effort is.
I like Chris' approach with SciML or Steven Brunton or Nathan Kutz and others, because it is still data-driven and are the same techniques, but are not applied blindingly.

elements.text:

Then they realize that these techniques are very hard to use if you don't have domain (actual) knowledge. The techniques are not a fad, but the hype and the expectation that it will (magically) solve everything without much effort is.
I like Chris' approach with SciML or Steven Brunton or Nathan Kutz and others, because it is still data-driven and are the same techniques, but are not applied blindingly.

text:
I remember how being a “data scientist” got so hyped, people rushing to take DS boot camps, looking for the rather larger bump in salary.  I used to go to the Open Data Science Conferences and related events myself, having interests in big data, healthcare IT, and NLP. I met a lot of great people then, who really did have the background and domain knowledge.
I worried that a lot of bad data science, from people who didn’t really understand statistics, for example, might end up poisoning the well for them.

text: Just a general point, doing what everyone else is doing puts you in a bigger job pool, but makes you completely undistinguished from anyone else and just puts you in the pile. Some people do well in the pile. Others might do better with knowing people and directly demonstrating their worth. That is easier by choosing a subcommunity that really cares about a topic, and matching it well.

That is easier by choosing a subcommunity that really cares about a topic, and matching it well.

text: Being only a generalist is a bad idea. You'll always lose out to someone specialized, since there's always someone. Choose to specialize in something, do it well, and people will care about you. Do the general thing AND something, or expect to be overlooked by the person who has the "AND something" for each job. Could by Python + chemical engineering, could be Julia + ML, etc.

elements.text: Being only a generalist is a bad idea. You'll always lose out to someone specialized, since there's always someone. Choose to specialize in something, do it well, and people will care about you. Do the general thing AND something, or expect to be overlooked by the person who has the "AND something" for each job. Could by Python + chemical engineering, could be Julia + ML, etc.

text: Let's keep in mind that OP was asking about a _career change_ though - there's no prior experience or direct connections that could help them here. Switching from some Python/C++ job to a julia job is not a career change. Jumping directly into julia without being able to rely on an existing position in the field is an extremely risky move for an individual

text: So yes, I agree, if I as an interviewer had to pick between someone who only knew Python/c++ and someone who knew Python/C++ and Julia, I'd probabyl pick the latter more often than the former - but that's not the case for the question OP asked. It's julia OR python, not both. Without prior experience in the field, if my tooling is python, I'd definitely pick the person wo knows python.

text: The OP has domain knowledge in petrochemical engineering, lots of things where that sort of background, combined with Julia skills (and at least reading proficiency in Python) , would be highly desirable.

text:
> Jumping directly into julia without being able to rely on an existing position in the field is an extremely risky move for an individual
I'd say throwing yourself into the pile of "just" Python ML is a bold and risky move. There's thousands of undergrads graduating with that every year, why would you ever pick someone not coming right out of school for an entry Python ML job? At least Julia/Rust/etc. ML jobs are looking for someone with a background that knocks out a good chunk of that pool, and you can start working towards it today. If you want to jump into an ML job as a later career change, you'd have to look to exploit your previous background, so petroleum engineering, which is an even smaller pool than the Julia community which is quite open. I'd say "ex petrol engineer who picked up some basic Python ML looking for a Python ML gig" will have a much harder time than "Julia person with petroleum engineering experience looking for anything with Julia in it, possibly with ML (which is generally the case)".

elements.text: Jumping directly into julia without being able to rely on an existing position in the field is an extremely risky move for an individual

I'd say throwing yourself into the pile of "just" Python ML is a bold and risky move. There's thousands of undergrads graduating with that every year, why would you ever pick someone not coming right out of school for an entry Python ML job? At least Julia/Rust/etc. ML jobs are looking for someone with a background that knocks out a good chunk of that pool, and you can start working towards it today. If you want to jump into an ML job as a later career change, you'd have to look to exploit your previous background, so petroleum engineering, which is an even smaller pool than the Julia community which is quite open. I'd say "ex petrol engineer who picked up some basic Python ML looking for a Python ML gig" will have a much harder time than "Julia person with petroleum engineering experience looking for anything with Julia in it, possibly with ML (which is generally the case)".

text: But also, learn more than 1 language. Everyone should know more than one anyways...

elements.text: But also, learn more than 1 language. Everyone should know more than one anyways...

text: Focus on learning the concepts as opposed to the syntax / semantics / ecosystem of a particular language.  That’s why Scheme was so great back in the day, syntax was trivial, but many concepts could be taught using the language.

elements.text: Focus on learning the concepts as opposed to the syntax / semantics / ecosystem of a particular language.  That’s why Scheme was so great back in the day, syntax was trivial, but many concepts could be taught using the language.

text: My point is that the python market is so oversaturated with postings looking for anyone that will take the job that choosing that is a safer bet than seeing if a julia position will work out. If they get a safety net that way, learning julia and transitioning to a less generic position will be a good thing to do (never said otherwise). But jumping directly into julia is imo going to be risky for someone without a background in programming (OP mentioned they're new to coding in general), since they'll have to compete with highly talented individuals who'll bring much more programming experience in languages other than julia to the table.

elements.text: My point is that the python market is so oversaturated with postings looking for anyone that will take the job that choosing that is a safer bet than seeing if a julia position will work out. If they get a safety net that way, learning julia and transitioning to a less generic position will be a good thing to do (never said otherwise). But jumping directly into julia is imo going to be risky for someone without a background in programming (OP mentioned they're new to coding in general), since they'll have to compete with highly talented individuals who'll bring much more programming experience in languages other than julia to the table.

text: If there's a position that's looking for petroleum engineers (or people with a similar background) and is also looking for julia people, that's amazing! I just don't think there's going to be a lot of those out there, compared to background+python

elements.text: If there's a position that's looking for petroleum engineers (or people with a similar background) and is also looking for julia people, that's amazing! I just don't think there's going to be a lot of those out there, compared to background+python

text: But yeah, the general advice of learning more than one thing and learning the concepts definitely apply.

elements.text: But yeah, the general advice of learning more than one thing and learning the concepts definitely apply.

text: well, that's the thing ... you don't actually know ...

elements.text: well, that's the thing ... you don't actually know ...

text: Just a tip, for that exact thing you might want to talk with Bernt Lie about the DigiWell project which is one group that's growing and doing reservoir discovery. It's in Norway though. There's a group in LANL too in reservoir discovery because of ARPA-E DIFFERENTIATE. Those are the two that immediately come to mind.

text: Being a contractor can work well, I worked for three years for a Belgian startup. Becoming an employee would have been quite difficult.

text: +1 for the learning & experimentation - I probably would have never tried to actively SIMD my code when writing C or C++, simply because all those intrinsics are a nightmare to juggle

text: I really want to see more materials for teaching programming using Julia at the high school & middle school levels, there are so many concepts that can be taught easily in Julia, it’d so good for learning and open ended experimentation.

elements.text: I really want to see more materials for teaching programming using Julia at the high school & middle school levels, there are so many concepts that can be taught easily in Julia, it’d so good for learning and open ended experimentation.

text:
> and also not assuming US/EU location
I agree that this is important to acknowledge. Even just north of the border here, I haven't heard of a single healthcare org using (or thinking about using) Julia. Most of them are just starting to pick up R/Python (if at all)! As awesome as <http://Pumas.ai|Pumas.ai> is, I don't see them expanding to our completely different healthcare system any time soon :smile:

text: That requires some degree of evangelism, which for my region and industry is also lacking. I'm sure it'll get better over time, but it'll also take a much larger Julia userbase in this domain to get that moving at an acceptable rate. In other words, still in the realm of aspirational rather than "I can use this to get a job tomorrow"
